title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act is titled the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" and allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The Secretary is required to act upon notice from a State judicial branch or agency regarding past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts. The Secretary is authorized to reduce overpayments to individuals by the amount of past-due State judicial debts and pay the reduced amount to the State judicial branch or agency. The Secretary can reduce overpayments to individuals by the amount of past-due State judicial debts and pay the reduced amount to the State judicial branch or agency. The individual making the overpayment must be notified that the overpayment has been reduced to satisfy a past-due State judicial debt. If an offset is made on a joint return, the individual must be notified accordingly. The overpayment is reduced to satisfy a past-due State judicial debt. If an offset is made on a joint return, the notice includes names, taxpayer identification numbers, and addresses. Priorities for offsetting overpayments are outlined in the subsection. The overpayment is reduced to satisfy past-due debts, including internal revenue tax, past-due support, and debts owed to a Federal agency. The overpayment is reduced to satisfy past-due debts, including State income tax obligations and covered unemployment compensation debt. The overpayment is applied to satisfy past-due debts, including State income tax obligations and covered unemployment compensation debt owed to State agencies or the State judicial branch. The overpayment is applied to satisfy past-due debts owed to State agencies or the State judicial branch, in the order in which they accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply for debts under this subsection. For this subsection, past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt refers to debts resulting from court judgments in criminal or traffic cases in the State. The curr_chunk refers to State judicial debt determined by a competent jurisdiction in the State, which is past-due and uncollected. This debt includes court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution. The curr_chunk discusses State judicial debt, which includes court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution, that is past-due and uncollected. The Secretary will issue regulations on how State judicial branches and agencies must submit notices of past-due debts. The Secretary will issue regulations on how State judicial branches and agencies must submit notices of past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts, specifying the required information and types of debts eligible for reduction procedures. Regulations may also include a fee for reimbursement to the Secretary. The regulations may require State judicial branches and agencies to pay a fee to reimburse the Secretary for the cost of applying reduction procedures for past-due debts. Any fee paid shall be used to reimburse appropriations that covered the cost of the procedure. The State judicial branch or State agency must promptly repay the Secretary for any erroneous payments made to them, as per regulations set by the Secretary. Section 6103(l)(10) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include disclosure of certain information to agencies requesting a reduction under subsection (c), (d), (e), (f), or (g) of section 6402. Conforming amendments are made to section 6402(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include subsection (g) for reductions under section 6402. Conforming amendments are made to sections 6402(a), (d), and (e) as well. Paragraph (3)(B) of section 6402(e) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for the reduction of overpayments for past-due State judicial debts before crediting them towards future Federal tax liabilities. Similarly, paragraph (2)(B) of section 6402(f) is also amended in a similar manner. Section 6402 of the Internal Revenue Code is being amended to allow for the reduction of overpayments for past-due State judicial debts before crediting them towards future Federal tax liabilities. The amendments made by this Act apply to refunds for taxable years starting after December 31, 2008, allowing for the reduction of overpayments for State debts before crediting them towards Federal tax liabilities.
